awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Large Arrays for 5G MU-MIMO Wireless Access Operating in mm-wave Frequency Bands
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project focuses on the development of a patented radio front-end supporting multi-user MIMO capability for the 5G mm-wave infrastructure market that would enable cost efficient, high data rate access wirelessly as opposed to cost prohibitive fiber-based data connectivity. Cellular and Wi-Fi networks are hitting a spectrum bottleneck in terms of their ability to offer higher data rates to densely populated areas and the same in a cost-efficient manner to remote rural areas. Advent of 5G cellular networks with new bands in the mm-wave frequency spectrum (between 28-70 GHz) alleviates these issues. RF Pixels' innovative mm-wave radio front-end will enable spectrum efficient communication through frequency re-use to spatially separated users at a fraction of the cost compared to known solutions. Thousands of mobile internet users can enjoy high data rates simultaneously without being starved of spectrum. Data heavy paradigms connecting consumer devices and the cloud, such as wireless virtual reality headsets and robotic personal assistants can be implemented with ease. Virtual and augmented reality based remote educational programs, online health care, smart cities, smart transportation and other new low-latency services will be enhanced delivering major economic and societal impact.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project proposes a revolutionary tile architecture that enables massive multi-user MIMO techniques for mm-wave radio systems, without the hardware and power consumption costs of full digital solutions. The radio can efficiently reuse the spectrum between spatially diverse users with active beamforming. Multitude of tiles will be used in a large array making it crucial to achieve excellent power efficiency at the tile level. Tile-to-tile variations hamper accurate beamforming requiring calibration. Beam discovery, refinement and tracking of multiple mobile users simultaneously requires investigation. In Phase I feasibility of a tile architecture that achieves multi-user MIMO and scale to large element arrays was proven. This project will investigate clock generation and coherent distribution to every tile in a large array for accurate beamforming and interference cancellation. Turnkey approach for packaging and antenna array design will be investigated. Impact of tile-to-tile variations on beamforming accuracy and calibration algorithms to mitigate variations will be studied. New algorithms will aim to achieve low-sensitivity to post-calibration errors without much downtime. Beam management algorithms for accurate tracking of mobile users compatible with guidelines of 5G NR standard will be developed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For this SBIR Phase 2 project, a remote radio unit (RRU) operating in the 5G millimeter Wave (mmWave) frequency band was designed and prototyped. This RRU demonstrated the support for multi-user multiple-in multiple-out (MU-MIMO) using multiple simultaneous spatially multiplexed beams from a single aperture. To our knowledge this was a world?s first demonstration of this capability where all the multi-beam capability resided in the Analog/RF portion of the designed RRU. In Phase 1 of this project feasibility of a novel architecture for such a MU-MIMO capable RRU was studied and proposed. Also a unit element (tile) mmWave transceiver and beamformer was designed, manufactured and tested using TSMC 40nm RFCMOS technology. During this SBIR Phase 2 project period -

  • A novel ultra-low phase noise clock generation scheme was developed and prototyped. Various coherent clock distribution schemes for a large phased array of transceivers were developed and tested.
  • The tile transceiver was packaged using a multi-layer die-on interposer technology to make it compliant with turnkey PCB assembly. A slant polarization mmWave antenna on PCB was designed, prototyped and tested. Multiple packaged tiles were then assembled onto a designed PCB to connect with the antennas along with other peripheral power management and control circuits.
  • A novel set of algorithms to calibrate impairments pertaining to transceivers and an array of such transceivers was developed. The algorithms were validated on a FPGA based platform.
  • Physical (L1) layer algorithms and Beam management algorithms were developed taking advantage of a custom serial interface protocol architecture for communicating to a multitude of tile transceivers. Devised algorithms enable initial access, beam refinement and beam tracking in real time. 
  • Developed algorithms were synthesized and integrated onto a Xilinx RFSoC development platform and validated for performance. 

  System integration of all the above developed aspects was performed. The developed system was used to demonstrate a 5G compliant MU-MIMO capable multi-beam mmWave radio. To demonstrate compatibility to 5G NR cellular standards further validation was done using industry standard test equipment. For demonstration purposes a 1x16 phased array was used as a base-station and multiple 1x4 phased arrays were used to mimic multiple users on the field. Excellent 5G link metrics were measured not only for a single link but also for a 2x2 MIMO link consisting of two simultaneous spatial streams from a base-station to two user radio units. Less than 5% aggregate error vector magnitude (EVM) for two simultaneous 64-QAM modulated 5G NR OFDM waveforms was measured showing two-fold improvement in throughput due to enabled spatial multiplexing by this architecture. Testing was also performed to compare the performance of proposed full-aperture beam-former architecture utilizing all the 1x16 elements against the same array operating as two separate 1x8 sub-arrays. In both the scenarios the array was used to transmit / receive two simultaneous beams. The comparison was done by varying the transmitted / received power (which is similar to what one would expect when a user equipment moves physically away from a base-station) and measuring the EVM of the wireless link. For both transmit and receive scenarios >3dB benefit in link margin is observed for the full-aperture array over the sub-array architecture. The result is better than the theoretical 3dB benefit due to higher inter-beam interference in the sub-array scenario leading to worse MIMO decoding performance. A sub-array has higher inter-beam interference due to wider beams as only fewer elements participate in forming a beam (here 8 as opposed to the full 16 elements). Thus for the developed mmWave radio unit reference, not only the compatibility to 5G NR cellular standards was demonstrated but also its superiority over commercially available sub-array based architecture was proven.
